segments.text: There was an increasing amount of anti-military feeling in America at that time.
What were your feelings toward that anti-military feeling, and was there anything that your department did to combat it or alleviate that feeling?
Well, of course, my concern was
with the Congress officially.

As I mentioned, I think the vast majority of the members of Congress, when I first entered this office and became an observer of the scene with the Congress, were in solid support of the Vietnam War, and every vote they took reflected that on a related issue.
I think by the time of this period you're talking about, by the end of 1970,
only the minority really was there.
And as you know, it wasn't long until congressional actions were being taken to really cut off the support for the Department of War.
But everyone in the Army had to be conscious of this problem and concerned with it.
The disenchantment of the people, particularly the youth, is true.
It can't help the Army.
You can only hurt.
But what do you do about it?
Really, it was a disenchantment with the Vietnam War.
And of course, the people who were conducting the war were in uniform.
And I don't think that it's entirely fair
So much criticism fell upon the military who were there doing the job as they were instructed to do it.
But nevertheless, it's understandable, I think.
And we saw, of course, very serious results of that feeling.
And I think the most serious that's going to affect us the most for the longest was the discontinuance of selective service.
And President Nixon came to the conclusion that that selective service system had to be discontinued.
And I think he came to that conclusion basically for two reasons.
One, there was such opposition to military service, particularly among the youth.
And it certainly had been demonstrated in those years of the Vietnam War.
And two, I think there were some proper
concern that a selective service system could not be conducted fairly.
How can you be just?
It had gotten into so many exceptions, you know.
Sure.
And the only reason you can justify those exceptions is because you don't need everybody anyway.
Right.
And, but the great cost of this, in my opinion, was evident from the time the decision, before the decision was actually made.
Now, I didn't feel strong enough about this that I would revolt over it.
And I don't think General Westmoreland liked the idea at the time.
But when the decision was made, those senior military people and secretaries of the services set out to make a volunteer service work.
But to me, and I said so at the time, the main hurt is not going to be the loss of that selection of men.
Perhaps enough bodies can be attracted into the services to man them, and man them properly even.
We didn't know at that time.
But clearly, what we stand to lose

most is the contact with the American people and their involvement in national security directly and what I mean is that when Johnny Doe was drafted almost inevitably I guess the sun is over the yard arm or whatever when Johnny
though he was drafted, Mom and Papa almost inevitably wanted to know, why Johnny?
Why does Johnny have to go?
And Grandma and Grandpa felt the same way, and maybe brothers and sisters and aunts and uncles.
Well, also, almost inevitably, after Johnny had been in a while, and they'd visited him at training camp and visited him in his outfit maybe,
Johnny had learned why, and they learned why.
We have to draft people because we have to have that much strength to meet our military commitments.
Now I'm not talking about Vietnam specifically, I'm talking about in general.
So not only Johnny, but his mom and dad and grandma and grandpa and aunts and uncles and brothers and sisters were involved.
And they became informed.
And this was extremely important to our, not just demanding the army, but important to our entire foreign policy and ability to carry it out.
We've lost that.
The minute the people were told that they were going to pay for an army, they might pay more.
But they were going to use volunteers.
They disconnected themselves from those concerns and those attachments.
Don't worry about it.
Just pay for it.
Sure.
Many people feel that they bought security, that they were buying security, but they weren't.
They were simply buying a peacetime service.
And there's going to be a great shock
if and when we have another crisis that requires significant mobilization and the Johnnies are drafted again.
Because a lot of people have just put it out of their minds.
Now, the question is, can we withstand that shock?
And I don't know.
To tell you the truth, I don't know.
When you combine that with the fact that we have fully accepted, as a nation of people, defeat at arms in Vietnam, we've long grown to accept a draw in Korea.
And we think we've bought security when we haven't.
The real question in my mind with regard to our national security is, do the people of this country have the will to provide for their security?
And that worries me.
I think we can have the best equipment in the world,
But if we don't have a willing and determined hand on the trigger, it doesn't mean a thing.
So we've got a lot of determination to be built back, I think.
And I think the best thing that came out of that tragic and frustrating

incident of our hostages being taken in Iran was the indication that the people do of this country do still have a feeling of patriotism and that's encouraging so maybe all we need to do is be put to the test but I'm very concerned that we've lost contact with international affairs and national security directly as families we think

we bought security that we haven't we have found it comfortable to accept a defeat and perfectly acceptable to accept a draw so why where and when are we going to be determined to win again what about testifying in front of Congress you must have done that on a fairly frequent basis is that true that's not
True, Terry.
I very carefully avoided that.
Yeah, did you let the Secretary of the Army do that instead?
We used the Secretary of the Army, the Chief of Staff, and other chiefs, and commanders.
Now, the reason I avoided that is that I could lose one case or be, you know, then I'd be ineffective as Chief of Legislative Liaison.
Right.
In fact, I testified only one time concerning whether senior officers should be permitted to be trained as pilots to fly Army aircraft.
What was your opinion?
My opinion was that they should.
And it was a rather interesting thing.
Incidentally, the Congress won on that one.

but our Secretary of the Army their opinion was no Congress's opinion was no yeah we had had a program by which officers would be chosen as senior lieutenant colonels or colonels officers who were promising this had been going on for 20 years uh well it had been going on actually for about 10 years when Vietnam when we started moving into Vietnam those officers would be chosen to be

necessarily but because they were promising officers who it appeared were going to go places and aviation was becoming more and more important in the Army and so we ought to have more senior officers from the combat arms particularly who are moving forward in grade and responsibility acquainted with the capability and limitations and the potential for the use of Army aviation
That's the theory behind it.

Anyway, that served us very well in Vietnam because we expanded Army aviation so greatly, not only in this 1st Cavalry Division, air assault, but also the 101st Airborne Division became an air assault division, and every division over there used aviation.
What about inter-service rivalry between pilots in the Army and the Air Force?
Was that a factor?
No, not really.
But I'll very briefly cover that incident.
The Congress wanted to cut out this program of training senior officers.
And the Secretary of the Army and the Chief of Staff were defending it, of course.
I just wanted to very briefly tell this little story because it's a little bit interesting.
Secretary of the Army and Chief of Staff kind of saw that they were losing the argument on whether to continue this training of senior officers so that they could understand aviation.
When they got higher command, they could use it better.
And General Westmoreland turned to me and said, Bill, General Becker, I think he said, you tell the members of the committee what you think about this because you're a product of the system.
And that was true.
I learned to fly after I was nominated
promotion of Brigadier General, because the general officers in that Air Assault Division were all pilots, and I wanted to stay.
So you learned to fly a helicopter then?
I learned to fly a helicopter, and I took the authority of the Chief of Staff of the Army to allow me to learn on the job.
And then when I came home for a brief leave, I split leave with training at Fort Rucker, our aviation center, and then went and returned to the division and finished my training.
I thought I gave them a good argument, but we in the end lost.

But to me, I was in a position of telling people where to go and what to do in aircraft, and when I learned to fly and went through the rigors ofby the way, when I was at Fort Rucker, they made me fly as many hours as I could do it because I was there just for a short time.
Of course, I had some ground instructions.
But they really worked me to the point of fatigue.
They had an excellent training program there specially made up for me.
I had learned in Vietnam, and the classroom emphasizes it, of course, how important this maintenance is.
And all you have to do is see a disaster that's a maintenance fault to realize what the responsibility for maintenance is.
So anyway, I outlined to them that
First of all, you need people who are basically oriented not on aviation but on the combat arms to qualify at some point in aviation and learn the potential of it.
If you've got a man that's done nothing but fly, and the Army didn't have many of those, but he's not the man you need to put in a position of command in this expanded use of aviation.
Well, when I learned to fly,
I not only filled a cockpit, which was unimportant, but I did.
I relieved another pilot.
I had a co-pilot.
But I knew in a much better defined way what I could ask people to do or expect people to do in terms of flying so many hours in certain conditions.
I knew much better whether you could land on that rough hilltop or not, and therefore whether you should order them to do so.
And I had a much greater respect for the maintenance of that aircraft.
And I said, beyond that, if you're flying alone in an aircraft, for example, on this maintenance, you're very conscious of it, solo fires particularly.
But I pointed out that when I joined the 1st Cavalry Division in 1941, everybody was on a horse.
And the commanders, particularly the senior commanders,
All the soldiers, well every commander, the soldiers expected that commander to be a good horseman.
And can you imagine being in a horse-cower division and not being able to ride a horse?
Well what's different in the flying aerosol division?
What did the congressman think?
Money?
Money.
Dollars were the answer.
And of course at some point dollars always have to be the limit, you know.
but anyway as a result that I thought very vital program was discontinued.
You had another question.
Yeah, I had some other questions about that job.
Congressman, who were the- you dealt with the congressmen all the time.
Who did you consider your friends from 68 to 70?
Who were your enemies as far as the military was concerned?
Who were people that would work for the armed services, and who were people who wouldn't?
Well, I don't think we really had any enemies.
Surprisingly enough, the members of the armed services committees in the House and the Senate, the members of the armed services appropriations subcommittees in the House and the Senate,
felt very much the same responsibilities as our senior military leaders and secretaries felt.
And they felt that they had to prepare themselves to present an authorization bill on the floor of the House and the Senate that they can justify
and that they can back up and that they can win with.
That's exactly what we've come to the Congress with to those committees.
Now, we have to sell to the committees, and then they have to sell to their own house of the Congress on the Senate floor.
So we're really, now they're not yes men by any means.
No way.
But it's interesting that those committees are a continuation of the process that we go through and a continuation of the responsibility felt
the security of the nation that our military and civilian defense leaders feel.
So you had close cooperation and coordination with those people.
So we worked with them.
You bet.
But they'd challenge us any time.
And any one of them could challenge us on a point or a program or whatever.
Who'd you have a lot of respect for?
Which one of the senators and congressmen?
Well, I couldn't name them all.
Let me just say this.
First of all, of course, the chairman at the time I was there of the Armed Services Committee was Senator Russell, briefly.
Succeeded by a no.
He had just moved to appropriate.
Senator John Stennis of Mississippi and Congressman Mendel Rivers of South Carolina was the House Committee chairman.
We in the Army have always felt the Congress was not an obstructionist organization, but they were so that blame slow that they were sometimes discouraging.
After two and a plus years of working with them and observing this process in actuality, I wound up with a tremendous respect for the Congress.
Well, first of all, for our total system.
I think the concept that our framers of the Constitution had was absolutely tremendous, and of course that's not a new observation.
The military men tend to be standing off from this and not particularly understanding it, but it works very well.
And the Congress itself, I left with a much vaster understanding of it and a very high regard for it.
And the members of Congress, by and large, they're very hardworking people.
I don't know of a body of people that work any harder, contrary to some popular belief.
They're very conscientious.
and they are there to serve the best interests of the United States, the people of the United States, and there's no doubt in my mind about it.

Now, we see the crook occasionally, and we see the deviate occasionally, but as I've often said, if you threw a fishnet over a hundred people in Kauffman, Texas, and then looked at them individually, there were two or three of them you would not want to keep.
And I think the same thing is just about in the same proportion in the Congress.
There's two or three percent of them that we shouldn't keep.
But I felt that there's absolutely nothing I would change except, if I could influence it, I would change the
tediousness and the time-consuming process, just as I've criticized the decision, the slowness in decision time in the Army, or the Office of the Department of Defense.
That's the only thing I would like to see change.
So you had real close cooperation with congressmen.
Oh, yes.
We had our critics, of course, and we had our incidents, and we had our bad news out of them.
but they're all very conscious of their responsibility for national security.
Okay, you were in this job when President Nixon was just elected.
Did you have an opportunity to meet the President?
No, I never met Mr. Nixon personally.
I've been in audience a time or two.
For example, he came to the Pentagon shortly after he was inaugurated and made a talk to the
General officer, general and flag officers, and secretary level people.
And I must say I was impressed.
And when you look back in retrospect, Mr. Nixon's long suit was foreign policy and national strategy.
Why'd you resign from this job?
That sounds like a fascinating job.
I didn't resign.
I retired.
Well, that's what I meant.
Yeah, Terry, I got you on a technicality there.
As a matter of fact, I'm still, I was not, I didn't leave the Army.
I was reassigned to the retired list, technically.
I could be called tomorrow if they wanted me and needed me.
Well, you had 1968 major general and two years later, then you retire.
You had a number of years that you could have served.
Yes, that's true.
Why did you decide to retire then in 1970?
Well, yes, I'd be glad to respond to that.
It was not an easy decision, and we decided, Fran and I, gosh, I guess ten years before,

decided that, really, we can go the 30 years in the Army, but we surely shouldn't go further given the ages of our children and the stages of life they'll be in, ready to start college at the end of that term.
We started our family a little late, as you see.
That was a conclusion we reached.
I shouldn't have called that a decision.
In Yugoslavia, then?
We were at that time, I believe-
at the War College, really you might say right up at the top of our career.
And I don't know whether I've said this in this interview, but I think it's appropriate to say that we certainly did not leave the Army because we were unhappy or dissatisfied or anything.
As a matter of fact, both of us will say that we never
I can say I never had a bad assignment.
And she would say, since we've been married, she never has experienced a bad assignment.
And in thirty years, the last five months, I had one son of a bitch box, I think I've said that.
We're going to get him, why don't you?
And that's a pretty good record.
Were you going to name him, or do you want to keep him?
No, I'm not going to name him.
Yeah, we're going to leave him alone.
I think I'm very fortunate.
I would say absolutely.
Now having arrived where we were in the Pentagon, and as we approached our 30th year, we began thinking about this again.
That was a fascinating assignment, and I don't know what was ahead, but we felt we should come to grips with this thing, and some of the contributing
factors to our thinking was that this was really a very unpleasant time for our children.
We were living, it appeared, in a very select location in Washington.
We were quartered at Fort Myer, Virginia, very near the Pentagon, beautiful situation.
Our children were being bused to schools in Arlington, which for years had been considered the finest school system in the nation.
And some of the things that had happened to our children, which were by plays from integration, were just almost unbearable to me.
The children didn't bother them that much.
So I guess this kind of got us, this didn't cause us to leave, but it caused us to think again about this.
And we could visualize that upon completion of this tour,
Our oldest son was, we had two sons, two daughters.
Our oldest son was a freshman in A&M at the time I retired.
We could be sent to Timbuktu or the back end of Turkey with these four children at these ages and say have one in college in the United States and one in high school in Switzerland and
American school in Ankara and us out at the back end.
And so family became the real consideration here.
And family had always been extremely important to me for reasons you've learned here.
And I've mentioned here that my children are fifth generation on this, fifth generation backers on this land here.
So I had to satisfy myself that I had fulfilled my duty.
I could have remained another five years beyond the date of my retirement.
Five and a half years.
And maybe another promotion.
Possibly another promotion.
That was not a serious consideration.
I was absolutely convinced the Vietnam War was over with as far as resolving it in our favor was concerned.
And so I felt that obligation had been met.
I had served there a year and a half.
I felt that I wasn't that essential to the Army.
We had
all kinds of highly qualified people coming on.
I'd had the privilege of sitting on general officer promotion boards, selecting officers for promotion in general, which is a very difficult thing to do.
But it was a very satisfying experience because
We could actually only select at that time for promotion a fraction of those who obviously were qualified.
Well, you see, that's pretty comforting for the future of the nation.
And so that's sort of a thing I rationalized.
As a matter of fact, each month the general officer in the Army get a listing of all general officers and where they stand on the promotion list and where they are.
you know, their assignments.
And I, while I was doing this contemplating, I happened to pick that up one day and I started looking at it with a new perspective.
I found among the listed major generals and brigadier generals, I counted 25 that I felt I had been instrumental in promoting.
by my reports on them.
So that made it easy.
I'd replaced myself 25 times, you see.
And by the way, one of the officers on that list is General Shia Meyer, who's now Chief of Staff of the Army.
So anyway, after all these considerations, but basically with the view to keeping our family together,
and getting them on home ground and letting their roots grow here, we decided we'd retire.
We'd be moved to the retired list, and that's what we did.
Did you ever find out what your next assignment might have been?
Yes.
Not specifically, but I was
I was told that I was to receive command of a division when I left the Pentagon, that I had been tentatively placed on that list, and that was very gratifying to hear that.
Because you had never had...
I had never been assigned as commander of a division.
I'd been assistant division commander of the 1st Cavalry, and I commanded it temporarily, but that's not the same.
Well, of course, that was rather enticing, but we'd made our decision.
And I might say, for whatever it was worth, and I'm not sure what it was worth, I commented on it in response, that I'd always had the objective of being a division commander.
And that's one specific objective that I had had.
And I wasn't disenchanted or out of sorts because I hadn't gotten one, but I pointed out,
that in my experience in World War II in Vietnam, I was absolutely convinced that the Army should never assign an officer to command a division if he's over 50 years old.
Now, that's an arbitrary thing to say, but I felt it should be, if much over 40, not much.
How old were you at that time?
I was 51.
So did you feel yourself that you were too old to command the division?
I felt I didn't put it that way.
But I did leave the thought that they should assign younger officers to command divisions.
Because the older we get, whether we really are ready to admit it or not, the mechanism is such that we become more conservative in our thinking and certainly more conservative in our doing.
And the division, and by the way, this age thing relates right on down, in my opinion.
The division is the optimum combined arms unit of the Army that brings all capabilities into play at the first time, first point.
And those are very critical people, those guys that command divisions.
And my observation of World War II at Vietnam was that those who were nearest to 40 were the finest commanders.
I don't know whether that was taken seriously or not, but I did note after leaving that many of them were young 40s who were assigned, mid-40s.
Now, that's not so much of you're deciding to do it, but it's a function, really, of the cycle in age versus grade in the Army, which is basically determined by wars, really.
Do you remember the day that you retired?
Very well.
Tell me about it.
Well, I had been offered a retirement ceremony at Fort Myer with the Old Guard 3rd Infantry Division during the honors.
That was normal for a senior officer retiring from the Pentagon.
That was the ceremonial unit there.
And I declined gratefully, saying that
I felt it appropriate only to retire with the unit ceremony if it were my unit.
So, the retirement ceremony itself was held in the office of the Secretary of the Army, and Fran was there.
The Secretary of the Army and the Chief of Staff and his assistant Chiefs of Staff and a few of my special friends were there for the ceremony.
And it was very simple, but very nice.
It sounds like it was very nice.
Very nice.
And I would love to have been retired at a union ceremony, but I honestly have always said, I don't want those fellows to be called out to march for me unless they've been my troops.
Yeah.
What were your feelings on that day?
Well, we've never looked back on that decision, honestly.
We've missed the Army a great deal.
But of course, that is a, that's kind of like, to some degree, kind of like that final review at A&M, you know.
It's a great chance.
It's quite a partition.
But we miss the Army often, and I think that's good.
But we've never regretted this decision.
As a matter of fact, these four kids of ours, we've succeeded maybe too well, in a sense, in getting this roots growing and orientation at home here.
Fran and I have liked it.
We thought we'd never get Chris out of the house.
But they have become very attached
to the point that perhaps there are better opportunities for them elsewhere, but they all determined to stay right around here.
Our oldest son lives and works in Kauffman, and our younger son lives out here across the road from us and works in Kauffman.
Our baby daughter just graduated from Sam Houston State University,
just gone to work in Dallas, but she doesn't want to live further away than Dallas.
She would like to move closer to her work there.
And our older daughter is out at Woodville and can't come home often enough with her two youngsters.
So that's been very gratifying.
Incidentally, both our boys went to A&M.
Chris didn't graduate, but they're also A&M products.
Very avid Aggies.
There's only two things more that I'd like to talk about.
And one is leadership, and one is the two more things.
One's leadership, and one is the change.
Another is the changes that have taken place at A&M.
Now I was wondering if you'd define leadership for me.
Well, I'm sure there are different ways to define leadership.
But to me, leadership is the demonstrated capacity to cause men to perform in the accomplishment of an objective, whether they really are fully oriented or not.
The better you are in them, the better it is.
It's causing things to happen, and happen correctly.
Is that motivation?
Motivation, when you start dissecting this leadership, I think it's in many parts.
By the way, I don't think leaders are born, I think they're made.
I think leaders are made through a series of accumulating experiences, dealing with others and causing others to act.
and growing situations of magnitude and responsibility and so forth.
Personality, of course, has something to do with it.
I think in terms of leadership, character is very important for the leader to have and show without, you know, to be observed without him showing it off.
I think knowledge of what you're about has got to be an extremely important aspect of it.
Of course, in military leadership, the ability to make decisions, useful and sound decisions, in a timely way is very important.
You know, it's an interesting thing.
most difficult thing for some leaders is to make a decision.
Now maybe we're getting back into this matter of conservatism versus risk, but leadership is something that you don't really develop so consciously by preparation, but by experience.
almost has to be successful experience and accumulation of successful experiences to really be a top leader.
I'm not saying that a failure is not acceptable.
It is.
Most of us fail at something.
Sure.
Is there a difference between military leadership and civilian leadership, do you think?
I think they're basically the same.
I think they're different in
you know, and the objectives that are... What type of values should a leader have?
What type of values?
Well, that's a good point.
That comes under character.
I think that a leader has to be a man of high moral values.
He's got to be just.
My experience is that you can be just as tough as you want to be,
as long as what you require your people to do is achievable and you're fair with them in doing that.
So you have to be fair and just.
How about flexible?
Well, I think... You have to have knowledge.
Flexibility, that's true, because situations change, but also you should be flexible in mind to the extent that you can accept...
advice, recommendations, and new information that leads to your decisions.
Flexibility is, of course, we can describe that against various terms, and when you get to the battlefield, it's a must.
It's an absolute must.
Are the people that become leaders in the military, are they people
who are the most capable people?
Well, this is sort of what we were talking about before.
Are they the most capable or is it fate?
Right there at the right time or is it a combination?
What was more important in your life?
I think it's a combination.
As you can see, if you're at the right place at the right time, you've still got to perform.
But if you don't get to that place, you're not seen.
You're not given the opportunity to perform.
And there's some variation and, of course, significance of jobs.
And much of that is a matter of chance.
Well, that leads to another question.
In a bureaucracy like a corporation or the military, you feel that leaders are basically the same.
Do you think that people advance because of their own work or because there's somebody else that's helping them along, or why?
Well, there's no question but what people you've convinced on your own capabilities can help you.
But at the same time, I'd hasten to add that I never considered
what has been referred to as politics in the Army as being really significant.
I don't think it is.
Who you know is helpful in many cases, particularly after you become senior and you do know more people and more people know you.
But I don't think that's essential at all.
Now, where it is helpful is like when you get, for example, when a general officer
takes command of a division, or a corps, or a higher headquarters.
Oftentimes, he's given some leeway in the selection of his staff or his subordinate commanders.
In peacetime, it's not very great.
In fact, it's almost nil in most situations.
In wartime, it makes more difference.
If he's got three records or resumes of officers in front of him, and he knows one of them, and the records look about the same, who's he going to take?
Sure.
And to that extent, it makes a difference.

Oftentimes, a senior commander, a senior general officer, having had experience with people, he'll just recall them and send a message watching, I'd like to have Joe Doakes to be my brigade commander.
And this will work to some degree, but I don't think that that's the determination.
Primarily, you feel it's the individual's record of work.
I think so.
You made general officer, which is the highest grade that you can make in the military.
Would you consider yourself, or did you consider yourself during your career an ambitious officer?
No, I didn't.
In this regard, if we mean that I said I'm going to be a general officer, I never did.
I had always felt that I'd like to be, but at the same time I realized I was going to get there one grade at a time if I got there.
No, I think my orientation accepted me to do the best job I could when I had the job.
Well, when you were 25, for example, did you say to yourself someday, and by that time you'd made up your mind you wanted a military career,
someday I want to become a general officer.
That's my goal?
No, I never said that's my goal.
I always felt that that's really the top.
Sure, I'm going to keep moving in that direction as long as I can.
And did you feel once you became general officer, once you became a brigadier, did you feel that now that you were a general that your expectations of what generals are like
Do you think that you had a good idea what kind of a status a general has?
Was it reinforced or was it refuted?
No, to a great extent I had an understanding.
